scenes.title: Deleting Instagram, gaining focus
scenes.main_point: Removing Instagram freed time and attention for intentional reading.
scenes.scene_summary: After deleting Instagram, I found more time, energy, and attention to read intentionally.
key_elements: Sense of regained time and focus
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person at home sets down a phone showing Instagram deleted, then opens a book and begins reading.
Quiet reading moment at a simple chair or desk, with a clear sense of regained focus.

scenes.title: Curiosity-led reading quota
scenes.main_point: Reading followed curiosity with a simple one-hour daily quota.
scenes.scene_summary: I read whatever sparked curiosity and aimed for one hour a day, minimum.
key_elements: Timer or clock at one hour
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person sits at a desk at home, turning book pages while a timer/clock marks one hour.
A simple daily routine is implied as they keep reading whatever interests them.

scenes.title: Two books and a Feynman warning
scenes.main_point: Both books pointed to Feynman’s principle: don’t fool yourself.
scenes.scene_summary: Two books quoted Richard Feynman: the easiest person to fool was yourself.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A person at a desk holds two books: “The Beginning of Infinity” and “Ego is the Enemy.”
On a nearby screen, the Feynman quote appears: “The easiest person to fool is yourself,” as the person pauses, reflective.

scenes.title: High ego blocks beginner work
scenes.main_point: High ego distorted reality and stopped learning and practice.
scenes.scene_summary: High ego made up stories, blocked beginner humility, and resisted boring practice like learning guitar.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
In a living room, an adult sits beside an untouched guitar while a kid nearby plays guitar better.
The adult hesitates, hands pulled back from the guitar, showing inner resistance to practice.

scenes.title: Reality check through rejection and progress
scenes.main_point: Dropping ego after rejection enabled steady skill-building and hackathon results.
scenes.scene_summary: After a hackathon rejection, I learned product-building, joined hackathons, and later placed as a finalist.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A person at a desk sees a rejection message on a laptop, then continues working with no-code tools on the screen.
Later, the same person collaborates with a small hackathon team at a table, ending with a finalist moment on a hackathon stage, determined.

scenes.title: Bad explanations and the humility to keep learning
scenes.main_point: Avoiding bad explanations required questioning, humility, and ongoing learning.
scenes.scene_summary: Bad explanations thrived under authority, so I kept asking questions and accepted what I didn’t know.
key_elements: Vast universe vs tiny Earth visual
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A lone learner stands in a simple study, holding an open book labeled “Galileo,” looking up at a wall sketch of a vast universe with a tiny Earth.
They raise a hand as if asking a question, expression humble and curious.
